description: From Middle French collegue, from Latin collēga (“a partner in office”), from com- (“with”) + lēgō (“to send on an embassy”), from lēx (“law”).

entries.meaning: A fellow member of a profession, staff, academic faculty or other organization; an associate.

verbs.description: colleague (third-person singular simple present colleagues, present participle colleaguing, simple past and past participle colleagued)

entries.meaning: To unite or associate with another or with others.
examples: Young Fortinbras,/ Holding a weak supposal of our worth/...Colleagued with the dream of his advantage,/...hath not failed to pester us with message/ Importing the surrender of those lands/Lost by his father. - Hamlet (Act I, Scene 2)
